Let me just advise the House what that grant has done: it has immediately meant that the price of a house increases on the day that comes in by the amount of the grant. That is what it will do. It will be the greatest inflationary move that the country has ever seen in home ownership.

The Treasurer was also very confident—`You talk about tax on houses. Let's talk about wholesale sales tax.' Does the Treasurer realise or is the Treasurer aware—today in question time he was not aware—that there is no wholesale sales tax on timber, on bricks or on the steel that goes into the reinforcing? There is no wholesale sales tax on 90 per cent of the materials that go into a home but now there is 10 per cent on everything, there is 10 per cent on the labour that goes into it too and everyone who fixes every one of those materials has become a tax collector for the Howard-Costello government—that is what it is all about.

It is about making the job easy for the Australian Taxation Office. It is about making it easy to collect those billions of dollars out of the pockets of the people that would not be affected if, I dare say, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister really were in touch with them—the battlers, the people who do earn less than $50,000 a year. As of 1 July they become the unpaid tax collectors for this government and they are the people that will be giving up one day of their weekend to collect it for the government.

What will they get in return? They will get a higher rate of tax. The lie has been sold, and it is a lie: the GST is the greatest lie that has ever been sold to the people of Australia. I have no doubt that the people of Australia, if they are not fed up with it now or if they are not afraid of it now, will be so over the next 12 months or whatever it is to the election. It does not matter how much selling the Prime Minister and the Treasurer do; they will not sell it because as we approach 1 July there is an increase—and it is an exponential increase. Already the accounts are coming in showing the effect of a GST on ordinary, everyday commodities and it will grow.

It is being passed on to us by big business and the shame of it is that it stops with the people who cannot pass it on. It stops with the low income earners and it stops with the pensioners. Big business are reaping the benefits now of having that money to invest on the short-term money market—there is no point in putting it into a bank account to get the interest—and they have the advantage of using that money at will until 1 July. They cannot pass it on to the tax office because, as far as the government is concerned, it is not a tax yet, but the people of Australia are paying for that tax now and will continue to pay it forever. That is the shame of the decision that has been taken by this government.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —One of the most disturbing aspects of Australian society today is the ever widening gap between the rich and the poor. The wages that Australian executives are being paid can only be described as obscene. The average executive pay packet has increased by 22 per cent in the year 1998 to 1999, whilst total male average weekly earnings have increased by only 2.5 per cent. That comparison in itself says a lot. Australian workers have to justify every pay increase they receive, and the government has fought every increase whilst attacking the working conditions and job security of Australian workers.

speech.para: But this is not the case for Australian executives. It would appear that the only justification for their pay increases is the greed of the CEOs and the inability of the boards to say no to them. It would appear that there is no relationship whatsoever between the pay increases that the CEOs have received and the profit growth, the share price gain or the return on equity of their company. There is no discernible relationship whatsoever between any obvious benchmark. It is impossible for an Australian executive to argue that their 22 per cent pay increase is performance based or is justified.

These pay increases are even more obscene when you examine the widening gap between the rich and poor in Australia. One in nine Australians live in poverty, two million Australians live below the poverty line and four million Australians rely on government assistance for survival. That is just not good enough. How can we in a country like this accept those figures? In Shortland, the electorate I represent, the average individual weekly income at the last census was $236 a week.

Let us look at BHP. BHP's managing director, Paul Anderson, receives a total package of $2,340,181. His predecessor, John Prescott, received a total of more than $11 million from BHP. Out of those workers who lost their jobs at BHP, there are still a large percentage of them who have not found any work. Out of 860 workers, only 130 workers have found jobs. Don't tell me that the packages that they received would come anywhere near the package that John Prescott received. The bulk of the $11 million he received from BHP was his severance pay.

I would also like to run through some of the packages that the top CEOs in Australia receive. News Corp's Peter Chernin receives $18.8 million. Let us remember that the average weekly earnings in Shortland were $236 per week. Rupert Murdoch receives $9.75 million from News Corp. Leon Davis, Rio Tinto's CEO, receives $2.8 million a year. In the Hunter this week, 84 workers were sacked from the Rio Tinto Mount Thorley mine. For the people who lost their jobs there, what a Christmas present that was! What do they get? They get their severance pay, which is nothing like the severance pay John Prescott received from BHP. Then what have they got to look forward to? The dole.

The CEO of Rio Tinto has been rewarded for downsizing, for sacking workers and for causing hurt and anxiety within the community. There is absolutely no justice when you look at this. On one hand you have a CEO who is receiving more than $2 million a year, which he is rewarded for by sacking workers—by giving them a Christmas present that gives them no hope for the future. All they can look forward to is unemployment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to rise tonight and to share with the House the success of an organisation which is changing perceptions about mature age workers and their ability to find satisfying and meaningful work. A Gold Coast man, Brandon Charlesworth, founded the Grey Army 2½ years ago. From one man's vision and hard work the Grey Army is now a very real and potent force assisting mature age Australians, many of whom have turned their backs on unemployment or inevitable redundancy and have entered into gainful employment with a better quality of life.

speech.para: Brandon Charlesworth, aged 57, is living proof that it is never too late to change direction and to start something new. In the process of turning his retrenchment into an opportunity, he has inspired thousands of older Australians to start up their own small business. Brandon had 35 years of work experience and a company car when he was retrenched from a senior management position. He went out on a track now trodden by many mature age workers who have found barriers to finding work as mature age Australians. He concedes that after several hundred interviews his self-esteem was low and he lost a great deal of self-confidence. Brandon recognised that he was like thousands of other middle aged Australians who were unemployed and could not get work but had a lot to offer, so he found a way to assist those with similar feelings—by kick-starting the Grey Army.

The Grey Army is educating the general public and potential employers of the value of providing work for people over the age of 45. Today the Grey Army boasts 2,000 service providers who undertake household chores and maintenance. They include carpenters, bricklayers, plumbers, painters, cleaners, gardeners and general handymen. The Grey Army has expanded to incorporate new offices nationally. Its policy is that all people under the Grey Army umbrella have the right to earn a decent living. They should provide quality work at a reasonable price—a benefit to the householder.

The Grey Army has had an overwhelming response from members of the general public seeking assistance in introducing them to qualified and reliable tradespeople in the over-45 age bracket who could be trusted to enter their homes to carry out repairs and maintenance work. Under the Grey Army approach, each person is essentially working as a small business, either as a sole proprietor or with family involvement. Details of the Grey Army approach were recently outlined to the inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations into issues specific to workers over 45 years of age following unemployment.

Brandon is to be congratulated on his innovative approach and efforts to date. And he does not plan to stop there. His latest proposal involves the creation of the Grey Army Trades Training School. Its aim is to fast-track the training of over-40s tradesmen in a 12-month period, with the result of producing qualified, ticket holding tradesmen at work in the community. Brandon believes he could put 500 people in employment tomorrow if he could access 500 qualified carpenters, tilers, painters or bricklayers. He stressed that they would not take existing work from other qualified tradesmen. To achieve this, Brandon's Grey Army Trades Training School would provide on-the-job training, which would involve one person per discipline acting as a supervisor. This supervisor would go on site to monitor work done by tradesmen at least three times during each job to check quality and to give advice when needed. Administrative training would involve such facets as basic computer literacy and bookkeeping skills, access to government and semigovernment authorities and requirements, insurance requirements for small business operators, debt collections and public relations skills, including good customer relations, telephone manner and presentation.

The Grey Army has restored Brandon's faith not only in himself but also in society. He gets a great kick out of helping others. According to Brandon, there is enormous potential for the Australian economy if we can unlock this source of labour. A combination of policies to increase the participation of 55- to 64-year-olds and to encourage the participation of 65-year-olds could deliver substantial benefits to the economy.

Mature age unemployment is a very real social concern for this nation. The plight of mature age unemployed people until now has been largely overlooked. There is a need for us as a society to examine the messages that are being communicated to ensure that stereotypes about older people are not being inad vertently reinforced. There is also a need for us to identify clearly why mature age people have so much difficulty in gaining employment after they lose their jobs. An inquiry into mature age workers being carried out by the Commonwealth parliament is a step in the right direction. I applaud Brandon's efforts to create work for mature age Australians and would like to see the federal government get behind the Grey Army.

talk.start.para: —The opposition have decided to support the government's proposed refugee legislation that would see three-year temporary visas being granted to refugees. However, I share the view of Con Sciacca, the opposition shadow minister for immigration, and the opposition that these temporary visas alone are hardly likely to act as a deterrent to the alleged 10,000 Middle Eastern villagers who, according to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, are apparently packing up their belongings and heading towards our shores.

speech.para: The Labor Party took the sensible view that, even if the coalition government's rhetoric was exaggerated, we could not stand by while people arrived illegally by boat or plane and pushed their way ahead of other refugees who come to Australia via our orderly refugee program. Money alone would determine your ability to come to Australia if that were the case, and we would allow the illegal onshore arrivals to push their way to the head of the queue. Even if the boat arrivals were real refugees, letting the current situation stand would mean illegals would force themselves on us over equally or more deserving refugees who may not have the financial resources or who may have been patiently waiting in wretched circumstances to come to Australia.

Of course, not all of the new boat people who come are legitimate refugees, but it is interesting to note that a very large number of onshore arrivals have achieved refugee status under our strict Australian codes. I ask people to imagine that they are an Iraqi merchant now living in exile, perhaps in Amman, who has perhaps fled the `gentle embrace' of Saddam Hussein or to put themselves in the sandals of an Afghan woman or an educated Afghan professor living in a refugee camp in Pakistan in fear of the Islamic zealots of the Taliban. Do you think a three-year temporary visa would deter you from coming to Australia? It seems there are those in the government who think the three-year visa is a panacea for this problem. Those who are advising the current coalition seem more afraid, in my view, of a Hansonite backlash in Queensland than an Iraqi refugee invasion in Western Australia.

The Labor Party has advanced an excellent plan for a special service or coastguard that would be mandated with handling this problem. But this is not the only thing the federal government should be doing. The federal government should send high-powered emissaries to Pakistan, Jordan, Indonesia and Iran to lobby these governments that are currently turning a blind eye to the people smugglers. We should be asking the assistance of these governments to stop these people at source. If the government is serious about these matters, then in my view there is an ideal person who would be such a senior emissary. The member for Farrer, the former Deputy Prime Minister, has excellent contacts in the Islamic world, and indeed has extensive contacts and influence throughout the Arab world. This may allow him to use persuasion that legislation or draconian action in this country would never achieve. Certainly in Iran, Australia ought to have some influence. A table supplied to me by the Minister for Trade shows that the Export Finance Incentive Scheme has supported exports from Australia to Iran of some hundreds of millions of dollars over the last few years. Australia has spent a lot of money subsidising agricultural exports to these countries; perhaps the Australian taxpayer could get a bit of a `quid pro quo'.

We ought to see this problem in the context of the number of illegal immigrants who have gone to other countries. As Gerard Henderson and Mary Crook pointed out, the number of illegals received in Britain in the last year was 51,759; in Germany, 98,644; and in North America, including the United States and Canada, 427,135. I would urge the Australian people and this parliament not to panic. Let us act coolly. Let us not denigrate these new boat refugees. Let us think a little laterally about how this problem might be handled.

I would conclude that the solution to this illegal trafficking in boat people probably lies more than anywhere in our relations with Jakarta. That is where the Australian government ought to be addressing its principal activities in response to this illegal trafficking of people by boat.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to pay tribute to a great Australian—someone who was a constituent of mine and, more particularly, a valued friend: Morris West. Morris West was a profound man—a man of erudition, complexity and love. His voice had a certain cadence which I can and will forever hear in my head when I read his words. He could and did keep a dinner table spellbound by the sheer breadth of his knowledge, and yet his charm was incalculable. This was a man who left an indelible mark upon me and upon many others.

speech.para: Morris was born in Melbourne's bayside suburb of St Kilda in 1916, the eldest of six children of an Irish-Catholic Australian family. He left his local school at the age of 14 to enter a Christian Brothers College in Sydney where he trained for 12 years. He did not take his final vows but said of himself subsequently, `I am one of the faithful in spite of my reputation as a critic of the church.' During World War II Morris served as an intelligence officer involved in code breaking at Melbourne's Victoria Barracks where he got a job by telling the Director of Intelligence that he was `competent in half a dozen European languages and adequate in a few more'. Morris was posted to the Northern Territory and whilst based there he wrote his first novel, Moon in my Pocket, which was published in 1943 under the name of Julian Morris. He is recorded as having said, `After my experience as a novice, the disciplines of army training were a cakewalk.'

Former Prime Minister Billy Hughes plucked Morris West from the armed forces and employed him on the recommendation of his publisher who described Morris as a `young man of promise'. For Billy Hughes, Morris West, like so many before and after him, had promise that lasted only three months. After that, he worked in Melbourne in radio. Next he headed to Europe where providence led him to Italy where he met Don Mario Borrelli, a priest who was caring for street children in Naples. His first successful novel, Children of the Sun, soon followed but he only became a household name after his eighth novel was published in 1959—The Devil's Advocate. In 1963 we saw the publication of what is perhaps his best known work, The Shoes of the Fisherman, which predicted the election of a Pope from behind the Iron Curtain—a prediction which of course came true.

In between novels, Morris often wrote for newspapers, including the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age, the Bulletin and the Australian, where he grappled with the concept of political power and its impact on the future of the nation. Whilst some say A View from the Ridge was an autobiography, Morris had previously said that he did not need to publish an autobiography as, in his words, `the chronicles of my works and days have already been presented under the decent draperies of fiction'. In 1985 Morris West was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia and made an Officer of the Order in 1997 for service to literature, and I had the honour to be present, representing the Prime Minister, at Government House in Sydney in 1997 for that investiture.

Morris and his wife Joy returned to Australia in 1990 and settled in Avalon in my electorate of Mackellar. Here both of them were vital members of the community and generous with their time. As a much admired, respected and loved person in her own right, Joy's contribution will continue.

I often speak in my capacity as Minister for Aged Care of the need for the wisdom and experience of older Australians to be passed on to other generations. Morris did this. Vividly I recall his address to a prayer break fast which was part of the Pittwater Festival, which he helped found. He was a man who could convey the need for spirituality in a way which challenged your complacency and encouraged you to reach further than your own acknowledged limitations. As part of his wider contribution, he headed many important organisations.
It was while he was busy working on yet another novel that Morris West passed away on 9 October 1999. He will continue to be greatly missed by the people of Mackellar and, indeed, the nation.

talk.start.para: —All members of this parliament would have been involved in the selection of outstanding senior Australians in their electorate and, like me, would have been impressed with the enormous contribution that our senior citizens have made and continue to make to the welfare of our country both in paid employment and in a voluntary capacity. All of the successful candidates in the Greenway electorate are involved in helping their fellow citizens. Tonight I would like to speak about just one of the successful candidates because of his work in the local mature age workers program.

speech.para: Providing work for mature age workers—now defined as over 45—is a major challenge for all governments. Although statistically unemployment is falling, there is still a degree of insecurity in the work force, and this is reflected in the high number of mature age people unemployed. The inability to find full-time employment in the second half of one's working life impacts on a person's ability to provide a high standard of living in retirement. So the contribution that people like Ted Cohen, who is the Project Officer for the Salvation Army Blacktown Mature Workers Program, make to our community is invaluable. Ted retires at the end of this year from that position.

During the eight years that Ted has held that position he has assisted many clients to gain meaningful paid work and has promoted the mature age workers to employers, creating a network of contacts that have reduced the discrimination that often prevails when older job seekers apply for vacant positions. Ted has also worked with government and private agencies state wide to achieve outcomes for his clients and clients of other agencies.

Changes in federal and state employment programs and funding have placed increased administrative duties on his time and resources, but Ted has dealt with them good-naturedly and efficiently to assist his clients. The effectiveness of Ted's work can be judged by the many clients who keep in contact with him even after they gain employment. Ted's networking skills are exceptional, and all who work with him have reason to appreciate his vast knowledge as a provider of information and assistance in the field of job seeking. Ted is an example to the community and industry of the contribution that mature workers can make to our society in paid employment in the final years of their working lives.

Ted was born in Inverell, New South Wales. He spent 37 years in the New South Wales Police Force serving in country New South Wales as Officer-in-Charge and in metropolitan Sydney. During his period in the force Ted developed an audiovisual driving training safety kit and instructions. He also travelled overseas to demonstrate the kit to international police forces. During his working life, Ted has been involved with the Far West Children's Scheme and spent 10 years assisting the Boy Scouts and Girl Guides. He was also President of the Mudgee Rotary Service Club.

I now return to Ted's current position as the Director of the Salvation Army JoblinkMature Workers Program, where he has developed a one person office into one of the highest achieving placement programs in the state. He enthuses clients to achieve paid work and assists them in overcoming the various setbacks encountered by this age group when seeking to rejoin the work force. Weekly development training and group working was instituted to give skills and support to job seekers, a service much needed in the community to prevent loss of self-esteem and despair. Ted lamented the lack of training opportunities for mature workers. He felt that preference was given by TAFE to younger students, which is understandable. TAFE does not seem to have the resources to provide the extensive training needed to allow mature workers to adapt to new technology.

Ted also believed that large companies, instead of downsizing, should be required to retrain their work force so that workers could acquire new skills to be able to fit into new industries. He suggested that the now defunct training guarantee levy was and could have been a catalyst for the retraining of mature workers.

The extent of Ted Cohen's work can be appreciated by the following figures that have been compiled since Ted commenced work with the Mature Workers Program in Blacktown: 12,000 client consultations, 3,500 clients assisted into employment; 4,000 into training for employment; and 5,000 job seeker sessions and workshops. Of the many fine words spoken about Ted's work, I will leave the final comment to one of his colleagues, who on the eve of his retirement had this to say:

Ted developed and put into practice strategies to uplift and motivate despairing, defeated people who had all but given up. He nurtured, enthused and empowered them to achieve their goals towards employment and often effected many other positive changes in the lives of these people in the process.

talk.start.para: —Once again I rise on the issue of Ovine Johne's disease. The recent announcement by the Victorian Labor government to undertake an inquiry into the Ovine Johne's disease control program is to be commended. The all-party parliamentary committee of inquiry, which will hear evidence on the social, economic and financial impact of OJD policy on producers and the wider community, is to be preceded by an independent scientific review by 31 January next year and should send a strong message to all governments that the national OJD program is flawed, harsh and regulatory to the extreme. As one New South Wales farmer recently commented in the Land newspaper:

speech.para: The New South Wales Department of Agriculture should ease up on the people being hurt by its regulatory approach and reassess its priorities.

For months now, producers in the Hume electorate have been critical of both the national OJD program and the New South Wales OJD management program, calling for an inquiry into the way in which it is being managed. Surely it is time to re-evaluate the jackbooted approach of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, which have yet to produce a document which justifies the basis of the current program. The continuing activity by the New South Wales government is without precedent in animal disease control, resulting in the destruction of businesses upon which the wool, sheep meat and live sheep export industry rely on for a sustainable future. Farmers and veterinarians have been pressured into common law agreements which have effectively removed safeguards and protection available under statute from farmers and veterinarians, leaving them open to cavalier and unreasonable directions from the state. To illustrate the point I make, let me quote from a letter from one of my constituents:

My Husband and I have lived on a small farm (1,000 acres) for the past 15 years, and hereunder is a brief outline of the situation we are in due to the lack of a responsible programme regarding Ovine Johne's Disease.
We have always purchased our merino rams from a stud in Grenfell, and approximately 18 months ago we were advised by the owners that some of their sheep had been found to have OJD.

A meeting was held by the Rural Lands Protection Board at our Local Bowling Club a short while later. My Husband attended this meeting, along with other farmers who had purchased rams from this stud. A few options were given:
All rams could be blood tested, but this was only 75 per cent accurate.
De-stock for two years.
Execute rams and if "negative" wait for 12 months and then your farm would be considered "free of OJD".
After a lot of thought we decided to take option "3" and had our four rams executed and a post-mortem performed, and the result was "negative" on all rams.

We were then advised by the RLPB that we were now rated "suspect" and had to have 450 of our sheep blood tested, and if they also were negative, then we would be on another rate, BUT not "free of OJD".

The Board also encouraged us, very vigorously, to sign a form which stated that we were aware of our rating of "suspect" and could face a very hefty fine if any of our sheep strayed. Reluctantly we signed this form.

The Department did phone about a month ago to inform us that if we did find OJD on our property, that as our summers were quite hot, after one year the disease would be gone. A few weeks later my Husband was talking to the Department about this matter and he was told, if he de-stocked, he would still have to wait for two years before re-stocking. We cannot understand why, if we de-stocked, it would take two years.
We are now organising to have 450 of our sheep blood tested, but it has been suggested to us to wait as arrangements may be changed again.

The problem is that the rules are being changed too much. We were given the wrong instructions at the first meeting. The Department seems very concerned about farmers making sure their sheep do not stray to other properties, but not very concerned about setting up a programme and sticking to it. OJD has been around for many years, and if a programme is to be instigated then it must be well thought out, and adhered to—no changing the rules halfway through.

The most annoying thing is we had a post-mortem on our rams which proved "negative" and yet our stock is considered "suspect" and we are virtually quarantined, even though no OJD has been found on our place. With all the press this matter has been receiving, we are wondering whether we should organise a blood test on our sheep or not.

Added to this, we are now told we have to pay $100 towards the eradication of this disease. I have a fear that all this money will be wasted because the Department has not got a responsible program in place yet, even though this matter surfaced a few years ago. I also heard where Victoria has decided to suspend their arrangements. It all seems as though it was not thought through in the first place.

I also have grave misgivings about the way in which the New South Wales farmers organisation is supporting this program. I appeal to our minister and to all ministers of the crown at state and federal level to ensure that this absolutely disgraceful program is slowed down to stop this heartbreak and financial ruin for people such as the one I have just quoted, who is one of my constituents in the federal electorate of Hume.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to discuss the alarming state of funding and support for research in this country, in particular scientific research. My electorate of Chisholm is home to two CSIRO sites and two leading educational institutions—Monash and Deakin universities. Therefore, I was most disturbed upon hearing about the resignation of Professor Davies, the Dean of Science at Monash University. It has been alleged that Professor Davies was pressured to resign due to his opposition to budget cuts that have seen at least 70 full-time academic and general staff lose their jobs. One of the faculty employees is so outraged that they asked me to raise this matter in parliament. These allegations of intimidation are very concerning and demand further investigation, as they are undoubtedly affecting staff morale. A recent article in the Monash Campus Review states:

speech.para: The faculty has thus lost over one-third of its staff in under five years.
"Funding for the faculty of science has been drastically and disproportionately reduced," Davies said.
"Further cuts will mean that science is no longer viable at Monash. We will not be able to offer the full range of courses and some departments will go to the wall."

This is also an illustration of the enormous pressures placed on universities struggling to cope with increased demands with fewer resources. The way ahead must lie in new ideas, more research and the marketing of Australian made inventions and products. As Labor leader, Kim Beazley, says, we need to develop ourselves as the `knowledge nation'. However, there is one key ingredient for achieving this which, as a country, we do not currently have: a federal government that is committed to resourcing and supporting research institutions in our quest to develop new industries.

This government showed its hand very early by cutting a massive $800 million from higher education in the 1996 budget, slashing R&D incentives for business and, more recently, suggesting a new income stream for universities—a loans scheme that disadvantages students who can least afford it. In his infamous cabinet submission, even Dr Kemp has admitted:
Universities are facing higher student:staff ratios, less frequent lecture and tutorial contact, the persistence of outdated technology and gaps in key areas of professional preparation.

In my electorate of Chisholm, Monash University has suffered a range of cuts which staff say are threatening students' choice of subjects and undergraduate programs and will lead to a long-term decline in the quality of both teaching and graduates. This is most disturbing. It comes on top of cuts to the arts faculty and also recent cuts to CSIRO, most particularly in the division of forestry.

Where are we going with our research in this country? If we do not put money into these areas, we will suffer. As the government said in its recent green paper, this will just lead to a continued brain drain, and our best and brightest will continue to go overseas. It is about time the government viewed targeted spending in education as an investment in our future rather than a negotiable item to enhance the budget bottom line.

Our future prosperity is tied to Australia reaching out to new industries and capitalising on our wealth of people and knowledge. Until the federal government reassesses its ideologically driven desire to cut government services such as universities, Australia risks falling behind in the race to invent, innovate and stake out our place in the world as a `knowledge nation'. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Drugs: How to Drug Proof your Kids Program

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak about the How to Drug Proof your Kids Program. Two programs of this type have taken place in Mitchell. The program involves parents who really can make a huge difference in the protection of children against drugs, gives the whole concept of the fight against drugs broader ownership, equips and assists parents with information and provides techniques and confidence. Parents have the compassion and the will; what they lack is understanding and confidence in many instances.

speech.para: The first meeting on How to Drug Proof your Kids was attended by 400 parents in Castle Hill. The purpose of that meeting was to train or identify facilitators. Six hundred facilitators have been trained throughout Australia. Their purpose is to get together with smaller groups of parents—about 20 parents—and work through a six-week program which is fully researched, fully Australian and a very positive program. The purpose of the program is to equip and empower parents with practical skills.

Parents' roles have often been underestimated. Where parents are involved in the process of drug prevention, the risk factors for teenage drug use have been reduced. Parents are part of the solution but have been neglected by most programs to date. I have discussed these matters with the state Minister for Education and Training, Mr John Aquilina, and I will be looking forward to his response to having all schools in New South Wales offering How to Drug Proof your Kids as an option for parent programs in schools.

The success in the Castle Hill area has been magnificent. A recent study of six schools examining the drug prevention lessons for children to complete at home with their parents showed the best outcome. The children reported significantly less perceived peer use of alcohol, tobacco and marijuana as well as significantly less susceptibility to peer pressure to experiment with cigarettes. Fathers, interestingly enough, also reported significantly greater motivation to help their children avoid drug use.

The program, as I have said, is a six-week program for parents. There are notes, exercises and discussion points. Broadly, the program runs through the topics of why kids take drugs, how to educate kids to make good choices, prevention tools for parents, learning to intervene and where to get help, and a parents guide to handling relapses back into the drug scene.

It is an excellent program. I recommend it to all members. The program is available for members to get behind, to promote and to run in their electorates. I thank Barry Denton and the team at Castle Hill for their interest in this important topic. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Today I want to raise serious concerns about the Rural Doctor Retention Payment Scheme. Like the Central West Gippsland Division of General Practice, I want to indicate that I have serious misgivings about the scheme and how the government proposes to apply it.

speech.para: In the Latrobe Valley and West Gippsland, we often say that the government either does not know or does not care about the plight of our community. I think in this case it is simply that the government does not care enough to know, because in the application of this scheme it seems that it has made a number of significant blunders. From the original advice received, it was understood that the payments would be available and of benefit to all GPs who practised in any rural area in Australia, in accordance with their practice town category. This now turns out to not be the case, and the people in my electorate stand to miss out significantly as a result of this. Amongst the most serious concerns I have about the application of this scheme is the fact that it would appear that the government has based its decision not to include significant areas in my electorate in the program on incorrect statistics. I would like to point out some of them to the chamber in the time allotted today.

The basis for its decision was that Moe's hospital existed. Moe's hospital was closed by the Kennett government about 18 months ago. So that is not true. It also assumed that there was a population centre in my electorate called Thomson and that there was a 40-bed hospital there. That does not exist either. There has not been a population centre named Thomson in the history of the Gippsland region. It also assumed that Traralgon had two hospitals, one for acute illness and one for mental illness. They both closed due to the privatisation process that the Kennett government initiated and were replaced by a hospital in Traralgon West.

Traralgon West, it should be pointed out, is outside Traralgon. So there are not benefits associated with the Traralgon community being able to access it. I also understand that the Latrobe Valley, which consists of the main townships of Moe, Morwell, Churchill and Traralgon as well as a number of smaller towns and villages, has been lumped together and considered as a major regional centre similar to Ballarat, Bendigo or Geelong. This is clearly incorrect, as there are distances of several kilometres between each of these towns. There are numerous other anomalies and inconsistencies which I do not have time to deal with today.

I also point out that the GPARIA Index is not complete and that it is not a satisfactory index for identifying which areas are in need of this type of support, because it does not take into consideration socioeconomic status. In the Latrobe Valley and West Gippsland, we do need this program to work for us. We have just as many concerns as other regions right across Australia, yet because of the rigid administration of the Rural Doctor Retention Payment Scheme we will miss out. This is clearly inequitable. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this time to respond to an article in the Daily Telegraph earlier this week, subtitled `Pressure builds on Badgerys', about Sydney aircraft noise problems. I would like to make a couple of points. An airport at Badgerys Creek will not solve Sydney's airport noise problems; it will merely duplicate those problems. It is a fallacy to think that by building an airport at Badgerys Creek we will relieve the aircraft noise problems of Sydney. In fact, the EIS itself has said an airport at Badgerys Creek will not reduce aircraft noise; it may just briefly cap them.

speech.para: The problem of noise duplication is in addition to the obvious problems of air quality in Western Sydney. Ozone levels and fine particulates would increase dramatically as a result of an airport in Western Sydney—not to mention the problems of the cost of $6 billion to build an airport and the impossibility of trying to create adequate infrastructure to link an airport at Badgerys Creek with Sydney.

The answer to Sydney's aircraft needs is not to duplicate the problems in Western Sydney; it is to better use KSA until we can provide longer term solutions. Kingsford Smith airport is not being used efficiently. Over 30 per cent of the flights in and out of Mascot airport are planes with a capacity of 30 passengers or less. The average number of passengers in a flight in and out of Sydney is less than 70. World best practice is well over 100 and, in fact, it is approaching 200. Until we use Kingsford Smith airport more effectively for international flights, it is ridiculous to think of building another international airport in the Sydney basin. Sydney is the gateway to Australia. Tourists visiting Australia want to land in Sydney; they do not want to land at Badgerys Creek—1½ hours west of Sydney. We need to work on more effectively using the resources that we have got—using Kingsford Smith more effectively.

A solution to this is to move a lot of the lighter aircraft out of Kingsford Smith, thus allowing maximum capacity and landing rights for the larger aircraft. Moving some of the regional and lighter planes out to Bankstown is a feasible solution. It is not penalising the bush; it gives another option with cheaper landing rights. Therefore, with discounted fares we can actually give greater choice to people from the bush wanting to fly to Sydney. Those wanting to pay existing premium fares can continue to have the option of landing at KSA; those who want cheaper, discounted fares can, in fact, choose to land at Bankstown which, with more effective infrastructure connections, could be only 20 minutes out of the CBD.

The answer is to use Kingsford Smith more effectively so that we can buy time—perhaps 15 or 20 years—to more effectively develop long-term solutions, instead of rushing into a hasty, unpractical, unviable, costly and environmentally destructive airport at Badgerys Creek, which people do not want and which will not solve our problems. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The biggest and fastest growing industry in the Blue Mountains is tourism. How sad it is to see the local member from that area arguing for tourist operators to be denied access to international and domestic tourists through the second airport in Sydney. He wants to hurt tourist operators in his own electorate—a shameful thing for a local member of parliament.

speech.para: On another matter, the 60 Minutes program has once more shown itself to be unfit to broadcast current affairs in this country. It is unable to separate its editorial policy from the commercial interests of its owner. Its segment three Sundays ago concerning digital TV was a disgrace to the notion of journalistic independence. 60 Minutes failed to report the findings of the Productivity Commission, which are adverse of course to the Packer media group. It failed to show the very small difference in quality between high definition and standard definition TV. It failed to explain the prohibitive cost of high definition and the way in which it would deny Australian households fair access to other TV options, datacasting and the Internet. The Packers hate competition and, mark my words, high definition is a closed shop in TV.

Channel 9 is a shameless mouthpiece for the pecuniary views of the Packer organisation and, in particular, for its vendetta against Mr Paul Keating. This was evident once again early last month. On 4 October, James Packer said that Mr Keating should either sue the Packer family or put their feud aside. The next night on a loaded segment on the Nightline program, Paul Lyneham, as is his style, parroted the Packer view, arguing that Keating has not sued. It is absurd for Channel 9 to argue that Mr Keating needs to take the civil remedy of defamation to prove his point in this matter. This has never been a standard of proof the Packer family has applied to itself.

The next time James Packer and his parrot, Paul Lyneham, engage in such an argument, they might like to think of this: if defamation proceedings are needed to prove one's innocence, then by this standard Frank Packer would have been guilty of tax fraud in the matters raised in Newton's case in 1957; or, by such a standard, Clyde and Kerry Packer would have been guilty of break and enter in their notorious occupation of the Anglican Press building in June 1960; or, by such a standard, Kerry Packer would have been guilty of tax fraud numerous times in the 1980s—in the film scheme, the offshore auctions scheme, the Swiftsure Credit scheme, the Bishop and Sewell schemes, the Conpress Investments scheme and, most famously, the bottom-of-the-harbour tax scheme, in tandem with Brian Ray and Ian Beames. He has had more tax schemes than I have had hot lunches. But, then again, the Packers have never been keen on paying their fair share of tax, anymore than they have been keen on facing up to their fair share of market competition in the TV industry.

talk.start.para: —There is one thing for sure in this business we are in of representing people—if you smack of arrogance, they sort you out. We saw it at the end of the Keating era; objective commentators would say that that was what was the end of Jeff Kennett. The referendum yes case died because those who were promoting it were inside their comfort zone, satisfied they were right, without going out to talk to those who may have disagreed. In fact, since then they have been saying to Australians who voted no, `You are stupid or unAustralian.' That sort of arrogance does not go down very well in my electorate, and a lot of ordinary Australians are very angry with those who are making such statements.

speech.para: We see arrogance in my electorate also in the Soorley city hall administration in Brisbane. They are an administration which tells you rather than listens to you. They are causing people a great deal of harm and grief by their consultation style, which is essentially to mock up consultation and then to tell you what they think they have found out. People are starting to speak out. In fact, the response from the community is amazing. Ordinary citizens in Brisbane are now saying to the Liberal Party, `We would like to be candidates because of what is happening in our streets and in our suburbs. The Soorley administration is not listening to us.'

Residents in Beverley Hills Street, Moorooka, were told earlier this year that they had been consulted over matters to do with a bus route going down their street when, in simple terms, they were not asked. A resident from that street, Stephen Walker, is now standing as the Liberal candidate in Moorooka ward. They were also told that traffic calming issues—roundabouts, speed bumps and so forth—had come about as a result of consultation in their street and their area, and of course that is not the case. In Yeronga West there were bus route changes which brought about such strange things as not even putting a bus stop at the local shopping centre—in fact, the bus went past the shopping centre at about 60 kilometres an hour—and even produced a bus stop on Fairfield Road where a bus does not even go past. These were the great results of the Soorley city council's consultation with the community—consultations that never took place—but of course people are being told that they were asked.

People in Salisbury are angry, as well, that their buses are few and far between and that they wait an hour to get from Moorooka to Salisbury on the local buses which used to serve them far better. Now we find the local councillor in Moorooka ward and the local state member in Archerfield saying that, if the federal government does not build noise barrier fencing along Riawena Road, Salisbury, something is wrong. The simple fact is that, if those particular levels of government—local and state—were to put a submission to the federal government for funding for noise barrier fencing along Riawena Road, Salisbury, perhaps something could happen.

The Soorley administration at city hall smacks of the same arrogance and has the same support from the elites such as News Limited's Courier-Mail and various radio stations, so they should go the same way as the referendum and the same way as Keating. They deserve to go. The people will speak in March next year.

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY LEVIES REGULATIONS (VALIDATION AND COMMENCEMENT OF AMENDMENTS) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I do not intend to take too much of the committee's time in dealing with this particular piece of legislation. The main purpose of the National Residue Survey Levies Regulations (Validation and Commencement of Amendments) Bill 1999 is to correct an inconsistency between the starting dates of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (National Residue Survey Levies) Regulations 1998—the NRS Levy Regulations—and amendments that have been made to these regulations by statutory rule No. 182 of 1998.

speech.para: The National Residue Survey implements chemical residue monitoring programs and recovers the costs of the programs from participating industries. As far as the meat industry is concerned, these particular levies are mandatory and must be paid by producers. Cost recovery is in the form of a statutory levy. These programs form the basis for documentation that enables the Australian government to certify that raw food products bound for export and domestic consumption are free from significant chemical contamination. This is a very important process, because we are finding in many of the European markets that the demands being put on Australian producers are quite stringent and require that producers supply very accurate and precise information about the level of residues in the product.

Last year, the government put through a new act to cover the NRS levies. That act was proclaimed on 8 July 1998. Before this act commenced operation, the industry sought a decrease in the NRS levy for sheep and an increase in the NRS levy on lambs. The government sought to implement this request from the industry by way of regulation, and that is statutory rule No. 182. The date of this regulation was 3 July 1998. In other words, the government was trying to make a regulation under an act that had not been proclaimed. The government was apparently unaware of the problem and collected the levies from sheep and lamb producers at the new rate from 1 August 1998.

As a consequence of this inconsistency, sheep traders liable to pay a per head levy on sheep transactions were unintentionally liable for a higher levy rate than that collected from 1 August 1998. Lamb traders were technically liable for a lower per head levy rate than that which was collected. The problem only came to light when the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances noted the inconsistency in the dates. On 6 May the Chief General Counsel from the Attorney-General's Department delivered an opinion that, because of the inconsistency between the dates, statutory rule No. 182 was invalid. The government amended the regulation as of 1 September 1999 to ensure that the rate currently being collected is that sought by the industry. This fixed the present problem, but it still meant that levies on sheep and lamb collected from 1 August 1998 until 1 September 1999 were at a rate other than prescribed in the legislation.

The government had two options on this; it could have refunded the overpayment or retrospectively legislated to validate the rates of the levies collected between 1 August 1998 and 1 September 1999. It has chosen the latter with this piece of retrospective legislation. It is really interesting that, in other forums, the coalition has spoken very strongly against retrospectively legislating on a lot of matters, and here we have the government doing exactly that. It might not seem a big issue, but the principle that the coalition has enunciated in other forums obviously does not apply in this area.

The other issue is the incompetence of the government in this whole process. I think it ought to be put on the public record that this situation was created by that incompetence and it is now being rectified by retrospective legislation. I see that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has chosen to join us in the chamber; I will not regard his presence as a red rag waved at a bull. I was in the minister's electorate the other day. I happened to be in Queensland and was invited up to Hervey Bay. I was invited by the press to make some comments on matters relating to sugar and regional forest agreements. My only regret on the day was that I had not informed the minister that I was coming into his electorate

talk.start.para: —A massive breach of courtesy.

—Yes, it would have been a massive breach of courtesy. Although the reporter was very anxious for me to comment on those particular issues, I said no, that I had a private reason for coming to the minister's electorate. On that occasion I chose not to comment.

speech.para: I invite the minister to come to Geelong to see our wine and horticultural producers. The port of Geelong is a centre for the distribution of grain throughout the world, the largest bulk handling port. I would welcome the minister to come down at some stage, as I am sure he would welcome me into his electorate, and we will afford each other the usual courtesies of notification.

As far as this bill is concerned, I am pleased that the government is rectifying its mistake. It is probably regrettable that it has to be done by means of retrospective legislation. The Sheepmeat Council are in agreement with the measures that are being taken by the government. They are quite happy for this legislation to proceed, so there will be support for the legislation on this occasion.

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his comments on the legislation, the National Residue Survey Levies Regulations (Validation and Commencement of Amendments) Bill 1999, and the indication that the opposition will not oppose it. Thank you also for visiting my electorate, even if it was without my knowledge. I hope you spent some money on the businesses of Hervey Bay so they could benefit from a bit of Victorian capital.

speech.para: Hervey Bay was largely built on Victorian capital as people exited Victoria during its rust bucket days. It now has developed a very strong economy, with much assistance from the people of Victoria. I certainly accept your invitation to reciprocate the visit and I am sure that the same hospitality the people of Hervey Bay extended to you would be available to me in Geelong.

As the shadow minister indicated in his comments, this is largely a technical bill in that it legitimises what everybody believed the situation always was. There is an element of retrospectivity about it, but it does not retrospectively legislate any disadvantage; it merely puts in place what the industry, the levy players and all those administering the program believed the situation to be until somebody discovered that there was a small technicality which at least some lawyers believed was not adequately addressed in how regulation 182 was put into place.

This change follows a specific request from the industry. The new per-head levy rate was to have commenced on 1 August 1998 at the same time the National Residue Survey Levy Regulations were put in place. But, as the honourable member mentioned, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was the first to draw attention to the fact that there may be an inconsistency here. The Chief General Counsel confirmed that, while the regulation had been validly made, there was this problem with the commencement date of the regulations.

The sheep and lamb industry has recently confirmed its commitments to the levy rates provided for in statutory rule No. 182. The impact on levy players of this technical anomaly will be nil once the bill has been passed, as the levy has been collected since 1 August last year at the rate requested by the industry.

I thank the shadow minister for his contribution to the debate and the committee for granting it smooth and rapid passage. It looks like you might get a very early day today. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the question forthwith. The question is that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 June 1999:

question.para: (1) How many Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel received (a) Defence HomeOwner housing loans, (b) Defence Service Homes housing loans, (c) Home Purchase and Sales Expense Allowance (HPSEA), (d) Child Education Allowance, (e) Opportunity Seat Available Travel (OPPSAT), (f) subsidised married quarter or living quarter accommodation, (g) subsidised Board in barracks and similar accommodation and (h) funeral costs and expenses in the latest year for which data is available.
(2) What is the estimated annual cost to the ADF for the provision of each benefit referred to in part (1).

(3) Will each benefit referred to in part (1) be identified on group certificates under the provisions of the Government's A New Tax System (Fringe Benefits Reporting) Act; if so, what are the implications for ADF personnel.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Records of the number of Australian Defence Force (ADF) recipients of the above entitlements are required for Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) purposes. The following data was obtained from the 1998-99 FBT return and only relates to the FBT liability for these items:
(a) an average of 3,252.
(e) 974 ADF members and 1,709 dependants travelled on a individual sector.
(f) an average of 32,901.
(g) an average of 158.
(h) not applicable as funeral costs and expenses are not subject to FBT.
(2) The estimated annual FBT cost for each of the above is:
(a) $3.146 million.
(b) $8.013 million.
(c) $6.772 million.
(d) $0.480 million.
(e) $0.749 million.
(f) $101.034 million.
(g) $0.174 million.
(h) not applicable as funeral costs and expenses are not subject to FBT.

(3) The legislation requires that a single FBT amount is reflected on each individual's group certificate. If a member receives more than one benefit the aggregated amount will be reported. Generally, for those conditions of service that are in the nature of a personal benefit, the effect on ADF members will be the same as the effect on other taxpayers and members of the community, ie the FBT amount reported on group certificates will be used to determine individuals' liabilities for superannuation and Medicare levy surcharges, entitlement to income tested government benefits and concessions, child support obligations and higher education contribution scheme (HECS) repayments. The Government has decided that conditions of service that are not solely in the nature of a personal benefit will not be reported on group certificates.

subdebateinfo.title: Protection of Children and Cooperation Convention
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 906)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Did Australia on 25 August 1998 ratify the 1993 convention on Protection of Children and Co-operation in respect of Intercountry Adoption, known as Hague XXXIII within the Hague Conference system
(2) Did the Convention enter into force for Australia on 1 December 1998.
(3) With which countries has Australia made, or is Australia preparing to make, arrangements under the Convention.
(4) For which conventions in the Hague Conference system is his department responsible.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes
(2) Yes.

(3) The Convention establishes legally binding standards and safeguards to be observed by State Member countries participating in intercountry adoption among themselves.—As such there is no need to make arrangements under the Convention with particular State Member countries to enable adoptions between them to occur. If prospective adoptive parents wish to adopt from a participating country they need to make an application through their State or Territory department responsible for adoption matters.

Apart from the Convention, Australia has a number of current adoption programs pursuant to bilateral arrangements between the States and Territories and overseas countries. Those programs precede Australia's participation in the Convention but, in accordance with the Commonwealth, State and Territory agreements on ratification of the Convention, are to be renegotiated by December 2001 to ensure that those arrangements comply with the principles of the Convention.
Further, the State of Victoria on behalf of all States and Territories, and the Commonwealth are currently negotiating with the People's Republic of China on a new bilateral adoption agreement.
(4) Australia has ratified, or acceded to, the following Hague Conventions:
XI Convention on the Conflicts of Laws Relating to the Form of Testamentary Dispositions;
XII Convention Abolishing the Requirement of Legalisation for Foreign Public Documents;
XVIII Convention on the Recognition of Divorces and Legal Separations;
XX Convention on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil or Commercial Matters;
XXVI Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages;
XXVIII Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction;
XXX Convention on the Law Applicable to Trusts and on their Recognition;
XXXIII Convention on Protection of Children and Co-operation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption.
The responsibility for all of these Conventions lies with this portfolio.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Payment of Taxes
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 909)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: Does the GST apply to payments of taxes and other charges, except those taxes and other charges that are excluded from the GST by a determination of the Treasurer; if so, (a) how many determinations has he made and (b) what taxes and charges have been excluded from the GST by the determinations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: All States and Territories signed the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Reform of Commonwealth-State Financial Relations in June 1999. In signing, States and Territories agreed that the GST should not apply to some taxes, levies and charges. The parties to the Agreement are currently in the process of agreeing on a list of taxes, levies and other charges that will be outside the scope of the GST. The complete list will be promulgated by a determination by the Commonwealth Treasurer as set out in section 81-5 of A New Tax System Act 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to World Health Organisation (WHO) Environmental Health Criteria Series Volumes 100-187 No. 171 entitled `Diesel Fuel and exhaust emissions' which warns that diesel exhaust is probably carcinogenic to humans, and that inhalation of diesel exhaust contributes to both neoplastic and non-neoplastic diseases, including asthma.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to WHO press release WHO/57 31 July 1998 stating that European Ministers of Environment and Health are discussing and adopting the European Charter on Transport, Environment and Health; if so, will he be drafting, discussing and adopting a similar Charter for Australia; if so, when.
(3) Is the consumption of diesel fuel promoted by reducing the diesel fuel excise.
(4) Is diesel fuel exempt from the goods and services tax (GST).
(5) Will he maintain or increase the diesel fuel excise in light of the WHO's findings.

(6) Has the Government's attention been drawn to a 1998 report by the Scientific Review Panel of the California Air Resources Board recommending that diesel exhaust be classified as a toxic air contaminant; if so, has the Government (a) heeded the findings of the report that long term occupational exposure to diesel exhaust was associated with an increase in the incidence of lung cancer and (b) taken action to warn truck drivers, plant operators, rural workers, the transport industry and the general public of the increased risk of lung cancer that these workers have been shown to be exposed to; if so, what.

(7) Is he able to say whether (a) the US Environmental Protection Authority has proposed listing diesel exhaust as a probably human carcinogen and (b) in 1990 California identified diesel exhaust as a chemical known to the State to cause cancer.

(8) Will the Government adopt the Californian Air Resources Board proposals for controls on diesel emissions, including the use of economic incentives to encourage the introduction of cleaner engines and the replacement of diesel with alternative fuels.

(9) Will the Government adopt measures in line with those that the Californian Air Resources Board now requires for the reduction of emissions of toxic air contaminants (TACs) from diesel exhausts; if so, will the Government take steps to reduce the emission of TACs from diesel engines by introducing regulations that (a) introduce standards that restrict the amount of particulate matter that can be emitted by new diesel cars, trucks and buses, (b) control the emission of oxides of nitrogen from diesel cars, trucks and buses and (c) introduce roadside testing of diesel vehicles for particle emissions.

(10) Is the Government introducing more stringent emission standards for heavy vehicles under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act; if so, is it a fact that it will not be until 1 January 2006 that new vehicles will be required to meet the new standards and 1 January 2007 before all vehicles will be required to meet the new standard.

subdebateinfo.title: Office of the Employment Advocate: Complaint Procedure
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 962)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 11 October 1999:

question.para: (1) What procedure is followed in the Office of the Employment Advocate upon receiving a complaint under the freedom of association provisions of the Workplace Relations Act.
(2) What is the average time taken between receiving a complaint and any subsequent action before the relevant court.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The policy adopted by the Office of the Employment Advocate (OEA) in this area has been to strive to ensure compliance with part XA of the Workplace Relations Act 1996.

This will in the first instance involve receiving the complaint, determining whether it falls within the scope of Part XA and then planning an investigation. That investigation will usually involve statements being taken and documents being obtained and could involve the use of the authorised officer powers under s83BH. Once the investigation is complete (and if needed during that investigation) legal advice is sought as to whether a breach of the Act has occurred.

If there has been such a breach then there are a number of options starting with putting the matters to the person about whom the complaint was made (with the complainant's consent) and seeking to obtain voluntary compliance—for example undertakings or an education campaign may be appropriate. The particular form of voluntary compliance will depend on circumstances of the matter.

Should voluntary compliance not be successful the OEA could provide the material to the complainant and/or provide free legal representation. In addition the Employment Advocate could decide to take legal action in his own name.
(2) Based on matters taken to court so far by the OEA—211 days.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is currently in the process of revising Convention No. 103 and Recommendation No. 95 concerning maternity protection, which were adopted in 1952 (these standards had revised earlier ones adopted in 1919). It is anticipated that a new Convention and a new Recommendation will be adopted by the 88th Session of the International Labour Conference in June 2000, following a second discussion on the subject. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 13 October 1999:

question.para: (1) What financial support will the Government be providing to regional television broadcasters to help meet the cost of digital conversion.

(2) Is it a fact that the networks' estimates of the cost of digital conversion are $195 million more than the Government's estimate; if so, what provision has been made for an independent assessment of cost.
(3) Is the Government committed to providing Australia's 6 million regional television viewers with the same level of service and choice as Australia's metropolitan audience
(4) When will the decision be made on the level of Government commitment to the cost of regional digital conversion.
(5) Will concerns over budget outlays for Australia's East Timor military commitment influence the level or timing of funding for regional digital conversion.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government is yet to determine the level of Commonwealth assistance or other support measures to be made available under the Regional Equalisation Plan to assist regional commercial television broadcasters make the transition to digital broadcasting technology.

(2) In its 1998 Election Policy Statement Communications: Making Australia Stronger, the Government undertook to finalise assistance to be made available under the Regional Equalisation Plan after an independent analysis of the regional broadcasters' digital transition costs. This independent analysis, inter alia, estimates the digital transition costs for the regional broadcasters in aggregated markets at $261—$311 million. The $311 million estimated by the independent analysis is $195 million less than the $506 million in transitional costs estimated by these broadcasters.
(3) The Government is committed to ensuring viewers in regional Australia have access to a full range of television services.

The legislative provisions for the introduction of digital television require the Minister to conduct several reviews including a review into whether legislative changes are required to ensure that underserved regional licence areas are provided with up to three commercial television services. This review, which has involved extensive consultation, is currently being finalised and the outcomes are expected to be considered by Government shortly.

In addition, subclause 64(1) of Schedule 4 to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 requires the Minister to formulate as soon as practicable, a Regional Equalisation Plan which specifies the measures proposed to be taken by the Commonwealth Government to, inter alia, facilitate the provision of digital television and datacasting services by commercial television broadcasters in regional licence areas. In formulating the Regional Equalisation Plan, the Minister is required to have regard to the objectives specified in subclause 64(2) of the Act? including the objective of bringing to regional areas a similar range of entertainment and information services as are available in metropolitan licence areas.

Following the recent sale of 16 per cent of Telstra, the Government will now be able to use proceeds from that sale to implement its $120 million Television Fund. The Television Fund, a 1998 Federal election commitment, will enable SBS television to be extended to transmission areas of more than 10,000 people, and will also be used to fix television reception `black spots'. Under the Fund, SBS will also receive $2 million to enable it to establish a New Media Unit and $10 million will be allocated to assist self-help communities in remote areas to provide a second terrestrial commercial television service.

(4) The Government expects to be in a position shortly to finalise its consideration of Commonwealth support measures to facilitate the provision of digital television and datacasting services by commercial television broadcasters in regional areas.

(5) The Government will properly and adequately fund our commitment to East Timor. Australia's involvement in East Timor will place considerable new demands on the Budget—expenditure which was not anticipated at the time of the last Budget. The expected budgetary impact of East Timor will be outlined in the 1999-2000 MidYear Economic and Fiscal Outlook Report. The Treasurer has indicated that the Government will need to prioritise spending so that the Commonwealth budget is maintained in surplus. As always, the Government will examine all expenditure carefully and objectively in the light of its medium term budget strategy and its overall policy priorities and objectives.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1999:

(3) Is the Tasmanian Haven Centre well maintained.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No, I merely confirmed reports of damage to Puckapunyal haven centre.

(2) No, I refused open media access and was unaware that the Kosovars had issued an invitation to journalists. My departmental staff working at the haven centres have discretion to allow media access to havens. In the situation you are referring to the staff decided that it would not be convenient or appropriate to allow media access to the haven as a large number of Kosovars formerly living in Western Australia had just joined the haven. It would have been very disruptive to the comfort and privacy of the haven residents to allow the media access at that time.

(3) The haven centre at Brighton in Tasmania is generally well maintained although there have been some instances of graffiti. Some rooms have been kept less clean than is desirable but there have been no major instances of damage.

(4) While some Kosovars have put efforts into maintaining their accommodation, others have not. Damage at Puckapunyal was not an isolated incident. There has been serious damage to doors, fly screens, clothes lines, carpets and fences in most havens. There have been major issues with the removal of haven property including 50 per cent of cutlery and crockery. Electrical equipment has also been removed and heaters damaged. In one haven a computer virus was detected on a residents' only computer which could potentially destroy the whole computer network at the haven. Investigation pointed to a deliberate action.
